raw_text:
Gervais writing Simpsons episode
 
 The Office's Ricky Gervais is writing an episode of hit US cartoon The Simpsons, following an invitation from its creator Matt Groening.
 
 Gervais has already begun writing the script but is keeping its subject matter a closely guarded secret. He will also write a part for himself in the episode. "I've got the rough idea but this is the most intimidating project of my career. The Simpsons is the greatest TV show of all time," he said. Groening recently heaped praise on The Office, saying: "Everybody on The Simpsons is a fan of The Office - it's one of the best shows on TV in the last decade." Gervais has already said he would not guest star in the show as his Office character David, having left him behind for good in the Christmas specials. The Office became a surprise US success when it was screened on cable channel BBC America. The first series won two Golden Globes in 2004 for best comedy and best TV actor for Gervais.
 
 In winning it beat the likes of Sex and the City and Will and Grace. An American version was produced, but so far only a pilot has been broadcast - to much criticism that it failed to live up to the original. At the British Comedy Awards on Wednesday, Gervais was handed a special achievement award for writing. But The Office missed out in the best comedy show category to Little Britain. Matt Groening was also at the awards to collect the award for best international comedy for The Simpsons.
llama3.2:1b: Ricky Gervais is working on an episode of The Simpsons, following a meeting with its creator Matt Groening. Gervais will write the script and have himself appear in it. He's described as the greatest TV show of all time and has already praised The Office.
llama3.2:3b: Ricky Gervais is writing an episode of The Simpsons, with his character David not appearing due to the character being left behind in Christmas specials. Gervais praised The Office as "the greatest TV show of all time," while Matt Groening said everyone on The Simpsons is a fan of The Office.

The American version of The Office was unsuccessful, while The Simpsons received awards including best international comedy from Matt Groening himself.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, let me break down how I approached this task.

First, I read through the user's query carefully. They provided a lengthy text about Ricky Gervais writing an episode of The Simpsons and wanted a concise summary. My goal is to extract the key points while keeping it simple.

I started by identifying the main elements: Gervais wrote the episode, it's part of The Simpsons, he's already in production but keeps secrets, will write his own scene, mentions Groening praising The Office, first series success, and upcoming awards.

Next, I made sure to include all these points succinctly. I noticed some specific details like Gervais not guest-starring David and the lack of a broadcast, so I included those as well. 

I also wanted to highlight his fame from The Office's success on BBC America and the awards where he received an achievement award. This gives context about his recognition.

Finally, I organized all these elements into a coherent summary without any extra explanations or formatting, sticking strictly to plain text as requested.
</think>

Ricky Gervais is writing a season of *The Simpsons*, following Matt Groening's invitation. He has already begun the scriptwriting but keeps its subject closely secret. He will also star in his own part for himself. "I've got the rough idea but this is my most intimidating project," he said, praising The Simpsons as one of the best shows on TV. Gervais has not guest-starred in the episode due to his leave from the Christmas specials. The series won two Golden Globes in 2004, and an American version was produced, but it hasn't met critical standards. Gervais received a special achievement award at the British Comedy Awards for writing, while *The Office* didn't win in the best comedy category to Little Britain.
tinyllama:1.1b: Ricky Gervais is writing an episode of hit US cartoon "The Simpson" after being invited by creator Matt Groening, following a secret proposal from the show's star. Gervais has not yet given any details about the script, but it will be the most intimidating project of his career and The Simpsons fan since its popularity surpassed that of The Office in 2013. "The Simpson" gained critical acclaim for its first season, winning two Golden Globe awards and being a surprise hit when it was premiered on cable channel BBC America. Despite the show's success, Gervais has already turned down several opportunities to guest star as David, his Office character, stating that he would not return because of The Simpsons' impact in TV comedy. "The Simpson" missed out on winning the best international comedy award at the British Comedy Awards this year, and Matt Groening was also present to collect a special achievement award for writing the show.
